function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Conflict between reducing airborne infection risk and maintaining thermal comfort and reducing energy consumption during colder periods.","Impact":"Increased risk of airborne infection and negative impact on occupants' comfort, energy consumption, and costs.","Mitigation":"Providing guidance to resolve the conflict and optimize ventilation systems.","Technologies":"Advanced ventilation systems with temperature control and energy-efficient features.","People":"Occupants, building managers, and maintenance personnel.","Owner":"Building owners, facility managers, and HVAC specialists."},{"Description":"Challenging to quantify occupants' exposure to airborne virus particles, leading to difficulty in estimating the likelihood of airborne infection.","Impact":"Limited understanding of the risk of airborne infection and the effectiveness of mitigation efforts.","Mitigation":"Focusing efforts on estimating the change in likelihood of airborne infection under different scenarios and assumptions.","Technologies":"Advanced air quality monitoring systems and computational modeling for viral transmission.","People":"Air quality experts, epidemiologists, and public health officials.","Owner":"Facility owners, health organizations, and research institutions."},{"Description":"Most studies of airborne infection for COVID-19 have generated risk estimates based on the Wells-Riley approach, which may not fully account for the complexity of dose-response models.","Impact":"Potential underestimation of airborne infection risk for COVID-19.","Mitigation":"Exploring the incorporation of dose-response models in risk estimation studies for COVID-19.","Technologies":"Advanced computational modeling and simulation tools for dose-response analysis.","People":"Epidemiologists, infectious disease specialists, and public health researchers.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health agencies, and academic institutions."}]}
